awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: Towards Regulatory Compliance Software Engineering with UCON_LEGAL
awd_abstract_narration:
Software engineers need improved tools and methods for translating complex legal regulations into workable information technology systems. Compliance with legal requirements is an essential element in trustworthy systems. The research proposed herein will advance the cutting edge for creating more accurate,  efficient,  and reliable RCSE (Regulatory Compliance Software Engineering),  resulting in compliant software systems. System specifications typically concentrate on system-level entities,  whereas legal discussions emphasize fundamental rights and obligations discursively. This work bridges three cultures of scholarship and research: software specification,  law,  and access control. By empowering software developers and policy makers to better understand regulatory texts and the access controls specified within these texts,  current and future software systems will be better aligned with the law.

There are three main expected results of this work: (1) Framework,  methodology and heuristics to identify UCONLEGAL components in legal texts; (2) extended TLA (Temporal Logic of Actions) rules from UCONABC and mapping of predicates,  actions,  states,  variables and  obligations between UCONLEGAL and UCONABC; (3) validated and extended role-based access controls to meet healthcare and financial legal requirements through further development of UCONLEGAL. The impacts of this work are expected to be far reaching; law and regulations govern the collection,  use,  transfer and removal of information from software systems in many sectors of society,  and this research explicitly calls for models and theories for analyzing and reasoning about security and privacy in a regulatory and legal context.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed the ability to assess the readability of policy documents for requirements engineers for regulatory compliance.  Via automated text mining we were able to determine whether a document contains requirements expressed as either privacy protections or vulnerabilities; and establish the generalizability of prior work in the identification of privacy protections and vulnerabilities from privacy policies to other policy documents.   Another key outcome of this work is the ability address ambiguity in regulatory requirements for the expression of those requirements as access control rules that can be implemented to ensure regulatory compliance. Our published case study demonstrated software engineers are able to identify components of legal text that require supplemental expertise to resolve.  This is important because there is some work that software engineers can proceed on without having to consult lawyers, and lawyers can proceed with confidence when software engineers are able to identify when supplemental assistance is needed.  Additional work included work on privacy and security requirements within the context of Internet of Things devices.  In terms of broader impacts, this work bridged two stakeholder groups that are actively seeking ways to collaborate in an effort to ensure that software complies with federal privacy and security regulations.  The work was presented to both technical and legal audiences, as well as to a government agency's compliance officers and supporting researchers, thereby bridging important stakeholder groups for ensuring regulatory compliance in software within research domains as well as federal compliance officers.
